Award.AwardTitle: Feeding and Feedback in Active Galactic Nuclei
Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this project is to use the technique of integral field spectroscopy to conduct a systematic study of the circum-nuclear gas in a large sample of active galaxies spanning a wide range in nuclear activity, to identify the mechanism for mass inflow into the central black hole. Specifically, the research will (1) determine the incidence of gas streaming motions associated with spiral dust features and quantify the mass inflow rates; (2) map outflows in high excitation gas on similar scales, to investigate the relationship between inflows, black hole power and outflows. The work will test theoretical predictions that spiral instabilities on sub-kiloparsec scales generate gas inflows compatible with the accretion rates inferred for local active galaxies, providing new insights into nuclear triggering and fuelling mechanisms and constraining supermassive black hole growth rates in the local Universe.

Broader impacts of the work include training of undergraduate and graduate students in spectroscopic research techniques. Involved undergraduate and high school students will participate in the RIT Insight Lab's "Research Incubator," which offers many opportunities to promote their development.

POR.DRECONTENT:
There is compelling evidence that supermassive black holes (SMBH; black holes that have masses ranging from 1 million to 1 billion times the mass of the Sun) are present at the centers of most, if not all, large galaxies. Although most are dormant, when they are “fuelled” by interstellar gas, they become the gravitational engines of Active Galactic Nuclei (AGN) producing ionizing radiation and powerful gas outflows (“winds”) that can disrupt star formation in the host galaxy. Our aim in this project was to study these gas inflows and outflows in order to better understand their properties (such as structure, velocity and mass) and how they relate to the SMBH and the host galaxy. In order to do this, we obtained observations with the 8-meter Gemini North and South Telescopes, located in Hawaii and Chile respectively, of 19 carefully selected nearby active galaxies using a technique known as Integral Field Spectroscopy (IFS). Each observation produces a “data cube”, which has two spatial dimensions and a wavelength dimension, essentially an image in which each pixel has an associated spectrum (see Figures 1 and 2 for examples of data products derived from these observations). Careful analysis of the data cubes yields maps of the intensity of the gas emission, the gas velocity, and its velocity “dispersion” (a measure of local turbulence) and the maps in turn allow the gas flow patterns to be distinguished and studied, over scales of 100 to 1000 light years from the central SMBH.

Our results in general show that circum-nuclear gas flows are complex and diverse, often comprising several distinct components. In most galaxies, the main component is a rotating disk of gas, but non-rotational motions are also common, usually in the form of outflows but in some cases, there is also evidence for gas inflows. A somewhat unexpected result is that several galaxies show evidence for equatorial outflows – that is, in a plane perpendicular to the SMBH spin axis, which is traced on the sky by jets of energetic particles emitting radio waves. In galaxies which have powerful radio-emitting jets, these push through the circum-nuclear gas, causing disturbances, which while interesting in their own right, complicate the identification of gas inflows, or winds launched by the SMBH accretion disk. An example of such a “jet-cloud” interaction is shown in Figure 3.

As an example of the complex structures that we can disentangle with IFS data, some results from the galaxy NGC1386 are shown in Figures 4 and 5. In this case, three main gas components were identified. The first extends over the whole image and is due to gas rotating in the galaxy disk, which is illuminated at an oblique angle by beams of ionizing radiation from the AGN. The second is much smaller in extent (less than 500 light years) and is a bipolar outflow, with approaching and receding components emanating from the nucleus. The third component is elongated in an almost perpendicular direction and is probably an outflow in the equatorial plane of the AGN.

After isolating the various components that contribute to the observed velocity maps, it is possible to estimate mass outflow or inflow rates for the non-rotational components. We find that typically, both the inflow and outflow rates are much larger than the fuelling rate that is needed to power the AGN. This indicates that most of the gas that flows into the AGN is actually expelled in an outflowing wind; only a relatively small fraction (a few per cent) of the net gas flow is swallowed by the SMBH, powering the AGN in the process.

Analysis of the rich data set assembled during this project is continuing and we anticipate further insights into the gas consumption and recycling processes operating around supermassive black holes in galaxies.
